thread.title: Byelection test for Tony Abbott, Bill Shorten
thread.title_full: Byelection test for Tony Abbott, Bill Shorten | afr.com

author: Share via Email
title: Byelection test for Tony Abbott, Bill Shorten
text:
Don Randall with his daughter Tess, son Elliot and wife Julie. rod taylor Share on twitter by Phillip Coorey The sudden death of federal Liberal MP Don Randall has set the scene for a federal byelection later and the first real test for Bill Shorten and Tony Abbott.
The potential consequences for each leader are significant.
Mr Randall, 62, died from a suspected heart attack on Tuesday, shocking and saddening colleagues on both sides of politics.
He is the first sitting member to die in office since Victorian Liberal MP Peter Nugent died in April 2001, precipitating a byelection in the semi-marginal seat of Aston.
A federal election was due later that year and at the time, the Howard government was deeply unpopular and staring at defeat.
Just two months before, the Howard government lost the blue ribbon Brisbane seat of Ryan in a landslide to Labor after sitting member John Moore quit and forced a byelection.
But the government held on against a 3.7 per cent two-party preferred swing to Kim Beazley's Labor to win Aston.
To this day, John Howard cites that as evidence the government was already coming back and did not owe its subsequent election victory later that year solely to the MV Tampa crisis and the September 11 terror attacks.
 Mr Randall held the West Australian seat of Canning since 2001. (He won Swan in 1996 but lost it in 1998).Over the years, Mr Randall built Canning into a safe seat.
Apart from a scare in 2010 when challenged by Labor's Alannah MacTiernan, he increased his margin to more than 11 per cent at the last election in September 2013.
"What needs to be recognised is his seat of Canning was a true marginal swinging seat and Don, through very hard work in his electorate and very strong support by the people of Canning, has made it his seat for the last 15 years," said WA Premier Colin Barnett on Wednesday.
Significant consequences Out of respect, no one is talking publicly yet about a byelection but the parties are giving it thought because of the consequences for each man's hold on the leadership.
Labor has not yet decided whether it will run. A swing against the government would be good for Mr Shorten and Labor's morale, and vice versa.
A senior Labor strategist said byelections following the death of members tended not to swing very much. He cited Aston as an example.
"There rarely is very much movement above 3 per cent to 4 per cent," he said.
The year before Aston, there was a byelection in the safe Labor seat Isaacs after member Greg Wilton took his own life.
But the Liberals did not contest the election, the first to be held after the introduction of the GST on July 1, 2000.
Mr Abbott is still on notice concerning the leadership.
Despite the consolidation among colleagues, the government still lags Labor by 6 percentage points in the polls and the September/October deadline he was issued in February to turn that around is now likely to coincide with the Canning byelection.
Western Australia has been the Coalition's stronghold for more than a decade but that support has begun to wane along with the mining boom.
